645 })"

646 data-analytics-component-type="search" data-analytics-event="e_componentClick"

649 @focusout="onFocusOut"

666 0 }"

734

735 <div class="mf-typeahead__dropdown" x-show="hasFocus && searchValue.length >

736 0 && !isPending">

737

738 <ul class="mf-typeahead__dropdown__list">

739

740 <template x-for="(item, index) in items" :key="index">

741

742 <li class="mf-typeahead__dropdown__item">

743

744 <!-- [html-validate-disable wcag/h30] -->

745

746 <a

747 tabindex="0"

748 class="mf-typeahead__dropdown__link"

749 x-analytics

750 :data-analytics-click-text="item.text"

751 :class="{ 'mf-typeahead__dropdown__link--all': index === 0 }"

752 :href="item.link.href"

753 :target="item.link.target"

754 :rel="item.link.rel || item.link.target === '_blank' && 'noopener noreferrer'"

755 >

756

757 <span x-html="item.text">

758</span>

759

760 </a>

761

762 </li>

763

764 </template>

765

766 <template x-if="items.length === 0 && !isPending">

767

768 <li class="mf-typeahead__dropdown__item">

769

770 <span class="mf-typeahead__dropdown__link" x-html="`No results found for '${searchValue}'`">

771</span>

772

773 </li>

774

775 </template>

776

777 </ul>

1603<button

1604 class="mf-button mf-button--site-montefiore mf-button--light mf-button--base mf-button--rounded mf-top-bar__button mf-top-bar__button--icon mf-top-bar__button--burger"

1605 data-analytics-click-text="Menu"

1606 data-analytics-link-type="button"

1607 type="button"

1608

1609 x-ref="btnHamburgerMenu" :class="{'mf-top-bar__button--burger--active': isDrawerOpen('hamburger')}" @click="() =>

1610 toggleDrawer('hamburger')"

1611>

1612

1613 <span

1614 class="mf-button__ripple"

1615 x-data="{ active: false, left: 0, top: 0 }"

1616 @click="active = true; left = $event.offsetX; top = $event.offsetY;"

1617 >

1618

1619 <span

1620 class="mf-button__ripple__path"

1621 @animationend="active = false"

1622 @animationcancel="active = false"

1623 :style="{ left: `${left}px`, top: `${top}px` }"

1624 :class="{ 'mf-button__ripple__path--active': active }"

1625 >

1626

1627 </span>

1628

1629 </span>

1630

1631

1632 <span class="mf-button__icon mf-button__icon--leading">

1633

1634

1635

1636

4071 <div

4072 class="mf-flyout__dropdown__item"

4073 id="dropdown-panel-2"

4074 aria-labelledby="dropdown-button-2"

4075 data-analytics-click-text="Research"

4076 x-show="activeDropdownIndex == 2"

4077 :class="{

4078 'mf-flyout__dropdown__item--opened-once': hasOpenedOnce,

4079 'absolute': (typeof activeDropdownIndex == 'number' && activeDropdownIndex >

4080= 0) && activeDropdownIndex !== 2

4081 }"

4082 x-transition:enter="transition ease-out duration-300 mf-flyout__dropdown__item--enter"

4083 x-transition:enter-start="opacity-0 translate-x-20"

4084 x-transition:enter-end="opacity-100 translate-x-0"

4085 x-transition:leave="transition ease-in duration-300"

4086 x-transition:leave-start="opacity-100 translate-x-0"

4087 x-transition:leave-end="opacity-0 -translate-x-20"

4093<div class="mf-flyout-content" >

4094

4095

4096

4097

4098

4100<a

8096<a

8133 <div class="col-span-full lg:col-start-9 lg:col-span-14">

8134

8135 <div class="block-layout-builder block-inline-blocksection-header">

8136

8137

8138

8139

8140

8141

8142

8143

8144

8145

8146

8147

8148

8149

8150

8151<div

8152 class="mf-section-header mf-section-header--minimal"

8153

8154 data-analytics-event="e_componentClick" data-analytics-component-type="section header" data-analytics-item-title="Osteosarcoma &amp; Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma of Bone Treatment"

8155>

8156

8157 <div class="grid gap-16">

8158

8159 <div>

8160

8161 <h2 class="mf-text-title-2-serif">

8162

8163 <p>

8164Osteosarcoma &amp; Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma of Bone Treatment</p>

8165

8166

8167 </h2>

8168

8169 </div>

8170

8171

8172 <div class="grid gap-16">

8173

8174 <div class="mf-text-body-2-sans">

8175

8176

8177

8178

8179

8180

8181<div class="mf-rich-text" data-analytics-event="e_componentClick" data-analytics-component-type="rich text" data-analytics-item-title="" x-data>

8182

8183 <p>

8184

8185 The Montefiore Einstein Comprehensive Cancer Center center Sarcoma Program is one of only a few of its kind in the New York metropolitan area providing an advanced multidisciplinary approach to osteosarcoma and malignant fibrous histiocytoma of bone. Our  Cancer Center was one of the first NCI-designated in the nation, and—for more than 50 years—we’ve been a leader in the research, diagnosis and treatment of over 200 types of cancer. Our exceptional teams provide medical and surgical management of all types of sarcomas, combining their expertise to deliver comprehensive care in a single clinical setting.

8186</p>

8187

8188<p>

8189

8190 You can expect comprehensive, personalized care that meets the highest standards for quality and safety. And our Cancer Center experts treat all types of sarcomas, including:

8191</p>

8192

8193<ul>

8194<li>

8195

8196 Alveolar soft part sarcomas

8197 </li>

8198

8199 <li>

8200

8201 Angiosarcomas

8202 </li>

8203

8204 <li>

8205

8206 Epithelioid sarcomas and chondrosarcomas

8207 </li>

8208

8209 <li>

8210

8211 Ewing’s sarcomas

8212 </li>

8213

8214 <li>

8215

8216 Fibrosarcomas

8217 </li>

8218

8219 <li>

8220

8221 Leiomyosarcomas

8222 </li>

8223

8224 <li>

8225

8226 Liposarcomas

8227 </li>

8228

8229 <li>

8230

8231 Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors

8232 </li>

8233

8234 <li>

8235

8236 Osteosarcomas

8237 </li>

8238

8239 <li>

8240

8241 Rhabdomyosarcomas

8242 </li>

8243

8244 <li>

8245

8246 Synovial sarcomas

8247 </li>

8248

8249</ul>

8250<p>

8251

8252 Each week, our team collaborates with specialists from radiology, pathology, medical, radiation and surgical oncology allowing for the design of customized treatments specific to your type of cancer.

8253</p>

8254

8255<p>

8256

8257 When you need osteosarcoma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma care, turn to our providers who are passionate about ending cancer and addressing your whole health needs.

8258</p>

8259

8260</div>

8261

8262 </div>

8263

8264

8265

8266 </div>

8267

8268 </div>

8269

8270</div>

8271

8272

8273

8274 </div>

8695

9312

9313 <p>

9314<strong>

9315As an NCI-designated comprehensive cancer center, Montefiore Einstein Comprehensive Cancer Center supports the mission and guidelines of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The following information about types of cancer, prevention and treatments is provided by the NCI.</strong>

9316</p>

9364

9365 <div class="syndicate">

9366

9367 <!-- ********************************* BEGIN Page Content ********************************** -->

9368

9369 <h2 autofocus="true">

9370Osteosarcoma Treatment (PDQ®)–Patient Version</h2>

9371

9372 <div>

9373

9374 <div class="summaryPage">

9375

9376 <h3>

9377General Information About Osteosarcoma and Undifferentiated Pleomorphic Sarcoma (UPS) (Formerly Called Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma [MFH]) of Bone</h3>

9378

9379 <div class="pdq-sections">

9380

9381 <div class="pdq-sections">

9382

9383 <div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

9384

9385 <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/bone/hp/osteosarcoma-treatment-pdq">

9386Go to Health Professional Version</a>

9387

9388 </div>

9389

9390 <div class="key-points">

9391

9392 <h3 do-not-show="toc">

9393Key Points</h3>

9394

9395 <div>

9396

9397 <ul>

9398<li>

9399Osteosarcoma and undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS) of bone are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in bone.</li>

9400

9401 <li>

9402Having past treatment with chemotherapy or radiation can increase the risk of osteosarcoma.</li>

9403

9404 <li>

9405Signs and symptoms of osteosarcoma and UPS include swelling over a bone or a bony part of the body and joint pain. </li>

9406

9407 <li>

9408Imaging tests are used to detect (find) osteosarcoma and UPS.</li>

9409

9410 <li>

9411A biopsy is done to diagnose osteosarcoma.</li>

9412

9413 <li>

9414Certain factors may affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.</li>

9415

9416 </ul>

9417</div>

9418

9419 </div>

9420

9421 <section>

9422<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

9423Osteosarcoma and undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS) of bone are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in bone.</h3>

9424

9425 <p tabindex="-1">

9426 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45395&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045395&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9427Osteosarcoma</a>

9428 usually starts in osteoblasts, which are a type of bone <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46476&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046476&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9429cell</a>

9430 that becomes new bone. Osteosarcoma is most common in <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776825&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776825&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9431adolescents</a>

9432. It commonly forms in the ends of the long bones of the body, which include bones of the arms and legs. In children and adolescents, it often forms in the long bones, near the knee. Rarely, osteosarcoma may be found in <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45882&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045882&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9433soft tissue</a>

9434 or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=257523&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000257523&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9435organs</a>

9436 in the chest or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45070&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045070&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9437abdomen</a>

9438.</p>

9439

9440 <p tabindex="-1">

9441Osteosarcoma is the most common type of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=434562&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000434562&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9442bone cancer</a>

9443. UPS (formerly called malignant fibrous histiocytoma [MFH]) is a rare type of bone cancer that usually starts in soft tissue, but it may form in bone. In bone, UPS cells look similar to osteosarcoma under a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=638184&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000638184&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9444microscope</a>

9445. UPS is treated like osteosarcoma.</p>

9446

9447 <p tabindex="-1">

9448<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46031&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046031&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9449Ewing sarcoma</a>

9450 is another kind of bone cancer, but it is not covered in this summary. For more information, see <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/bone/patient/ewing-treatment-pdq">

9451Ewing Sarcoma Treatment</a>

9452. </p>

9453

9454 </section>

9455<section>

9456<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

9457Having past treatment with chemotherapy or radiation can increase the risk of osteosarcoma.</h3>

9458

9459 <p tabindex="-1">

9460Anything that increases a person's risk of getting a disease is called a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45873&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045873&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9461risk factor</a>

9462. Not every child with one or more of these risk factors will develop osteosarcoma, and it will develop in some children who don't have any known risk factors. Talk with your child's doctor if you think your child may be at risk. Risk factors for osteosarcoma include the following:</p>

9463

9464 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9465

9466 <ul>

9467<li>

9468Past treatment with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45214&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045214&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9469chemotherapy</a>

9470 or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44971&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044971&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9471radiation therapy</a>

9472.</li>

9473

9474 <li>

9475Having a certain change in the <em class="gene-name">

9476RB1</em>

9477 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9478gene</a>

9479.</li>

9480

9481 <li>

9482Having certain <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=651193&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000651193&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9483conditions</a>

9484, such as the following:

9485 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9486

9487 <ul>

9488<li>

9489<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=666662&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000666662&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9490Bloom syndrome</a>

9491.</li>

9492

9493 <li>

9494<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=666665&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000666665&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9495Diamond-Blackfan anemia</a>

9496.</li>

9497

9498 <li>

9499<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46322&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046322&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9500Li-Fraumeni syndrome</a>

9501.</li>

9502

9503 <li>

9504<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=350239&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000350239&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9505Paget disease</a>

9506.</li>

9507

9508 <li>

9509<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45983&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045983&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9510Hereditary</a>

9511 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46774&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046774&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9512retinoblastoma</a>

9513.</li>

9514

9515 <li>

9516<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=662024&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000662024&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9517Rothmund-Thomson syndrome</a>

9518.</li>

9519

9520 <li>

9521<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=666684&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000666684&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9522Werner syndrome</a>

9523.</li>

9524

9525 </ul>

9526</div>

9527</li>

9528

9529 </ul>

9530</div>

9531

9532 </section>

9533<section>

9534<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

9535Signs and symptoms of osteosarcoma and UPS include swelling over a bone or a bony part of the body and joint pain. </h3>

9536

9537 <p tabindex="-1">

9538These and other <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=750109&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000750109&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9539signs</a>

9540 and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45022&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045022&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9541symptoms</a>

9542 may be caused by osteosarcoma or UPS or by other conditions. Check with a doctor if your child has any of the following:</p>

9543

9544 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9545

9546 <ul>

9547<li>

9548Swelling over a bone or bony part of the body.</li>

9549

9550 <li>

9551Pain in a bone or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=458080&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000458080&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9552joint</a>

9553.</li>

9554

9555 <li>

9556A bone that breaks for no known reason.</li>

9557

9558 </ul>

9559</div>

9560

9561 </section>

9562<section>

9563<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

9564Imaging tests are used to detect (find) osteosarcoma and UPS.</h3>

9565

9566 <p tabindex="-1">

9567In addition to asking about your child's <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=642019&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000642019&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9568personal</a>

9569 and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=642015&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000642015&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9570family health history</a>

9571 and doing a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=270871&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000270871&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9572physical exam</a>

9573, your child's doctor may perform the following tests and procedures:</p>

9574

9575 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9576

9577 <ul>

9578<li>

9579<strong>

9580<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45944&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045944&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9581X-ray</a>

9582</strong>

9583: An x-ray of the organs and bones inside the body. An x-ray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body. </li>

9584

9585 <li>

9586<strong>

9587<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46033&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046033&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9588CT scan</a>

9589 (CAT scan)</strong>

9590: A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles. The pictures are made by a computer linked to an x-ray machine. A <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=409764&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000409764&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9591dye</a>

9592 may be <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44678&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044678&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9593injected</a>

9594 into a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=476471&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000476471&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9595vein</a>

9596 or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly. This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.</li>

9597

9598 <li>

9599<strong>

9600<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45788&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045788&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9601MRI</a>

9602 (magnetic resonance imaging)</strong>

9603: A procedure that uses a magnet, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=651209&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000651209&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9604radio waves</a>

9605, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body. This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).</li>

9606

9607 </ul>

9608</div>

9609

9610 </section>

9611<section>

9612<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

9613A biopsy is done to diagnose osteosarcoma.</h3>

9614

9615 <p tabindex="-1">

9616<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=689578&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000689578&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9617Imaging tests</a>

9618 are done before a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45164&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045164&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9619biopsy</a>

9620. </p>

9621

9622 <p tabindex="-1">

9623Cells and tissues are removed during a biopsy so they can be viewed under a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=638184&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000638184&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9624microscope</a>

9625 by a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46244&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046244&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9626pathologist</a>

9627 to check for signs of cancer. It is important that the biopsy be done by a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44306&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044306&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9628surgeon</a>

9629 who is an expert in treating cancer of the bone. It is best if that surgeon is also the one who removes the tumor. The biopsy and the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45570&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045570&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9630surgery</a>

9631 to remove the tumor are planned together. The way the biopsy is done affects which type of surgery can be done later.</p>

9632

9633 <p tabindex="-1">

9634The type of biopsy that is done will be based on the size of the tumor and where it is in the body. There are two types of biopsy that may be used:</p>

9635

9636 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9637

9638 <ul>

9639<li>

9640<strong>

9641<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45657&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045657&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9642Core biopsy</a>

9643</strong>

9644: The removal of tissue using a wide needle.</li>

9645

9646 <li>

9647<strong>

9648<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46698&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046698&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9649Incisional biopsy</a>

9650</strong>

9651: The removal of part of a lump or a sample of tissue that doesn't look normal. </li>

9652

9653 </ul>

9654</div>

9655

9656 <p tabindex="-1">

9657The following test may be done on the tissue that is removed:</p>

9658

9659 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9660

9661 <ul>

9662<li>

9663<strong>

9664<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44025&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044025&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9665Electron microscopy</a>

9666</strong>

9667: A <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46590&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046590&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9668laboratory test</a>

9669 in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under regular and high-powered microscopes to look for certain changes in the cells.</li>

9670

9671 </ul>

9672</div>

9673

9674 </section>

9675<section>

9676<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

9677Certain factors may affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.</h3>

9678

9679 <p tabindex="-1">

9680The <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45849&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045849&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9681prognosis</a>

9682 may be affected by certain factors before and after treatment. </p>

9683

9684 <p tabindex="-1">

9685The prognosis of untreated osteosarcoma and UPS may depend on the following:</p>

9686

9687 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9688

9689 <ul>

9690<li>

9691Where the tumor is in the body and whether tumors formed in more than one bone.</li>

9692

9693 <li>

9694Whether the patient has two or more tumors in the same bone.</li>

9695

9696 <li>

9697The size of the tumor.</li>

9698

9699 <li>

9700Whether the cancer has spread to other parts of the body and where it has spread.</li>

9701

9702 <li>

9703The type of tumor (based on how the cancer cells look under a microscope).</li>

9704

9705 <li>

9706The patient's sex, age, and weight at the time of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46450&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046450&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9707diagnosis</a>

9708.</li>

9709

9710 <li>

9711Whether the patient has had treatment for a different cancer.</li>

9712

9713 <li>

9714Whether the patient has certain <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46391&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046391&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9715genetic</a>

9716 diseases.</li>

9717

9718 </ul>

9719</div>

9720

9721 <p tabindex="-1">

9722After osteosarcoma or UPS is treated, prognosis also depends on the following:</p>

9723

9724 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9725

9726 <ul>

9727<li>

9728How much of the cancer was killed by <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45214&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045214&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9729chemotherapy</a>

9730.</li>

9731

9732 <li>

9733Whether the tumor has been completely removed by surgery.</li>

9734

9735 <li>

9736Whether the cancer has <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46556&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046556&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9737recurred</a>

9738 (come back) within 2 years of diagnosis.</li>

9739

9740 </ul>

9741</div>

9742

9743 <p tabindex="-1">

9744Treatment options for osteosarcoma and UPS depend on the following:</p>

9745

9746 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9747

9748 <ul>

9749<li>

9750Where the tumor is in the body and if it has spread.</li>

9751

9752 <li>

9753The size of the tumor.</li>

9754

9755 <li>

9756The <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=774694&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000774694&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9757grade</a>

9758 of the cancer.</li>

9759

9760 <li>

9761Whether the bones are still growing.</li>

9762

9763 <li>

9764The patient's age and general health.</li>

9765

9766 <li>

9767The desire of the patient and family for the patient to be able to take part in activities such as sports or to look a certain way.</li>

9768

9769 <li>

9770Whether the cancer is newly diagnosed or has recurred after treatment.</li>

9771

9772 </ul>

9773</div>

9774

9775 </section>

9776</div>

9777

9778 </div>

9779

9780 <h3>

9781Stages of Osteosarcoma and Undifferentiated Pleomorphic Sarcoma (UPS)</h3>

9782

9783 <div class="pdq-sections">

9784

9785 <div class="pdq-sections">

9786

9787 <div class="key-points">

9788

9789 <h3 do-not-show="toc">

9790Key Points</h3>

9791

9792 <div>

9793

9794 <ul>

9795<li>

9796After osteosarcoma or undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS) has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body. </li>

9797

9798 <li>

9799There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.</li>

9800

9801 <li>

9802Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.</li>

9803

9804 <li>

9805Sometimes osteosarcoma and UPS of bone come back after treatment.</li>

9806

9807 </ul>

9808</div>

9809

9810 </div>

9811

9812 <section>

9813<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

9814After osteosarcoma or undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS) has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body. </h3>

9815

9816 <p tabindex="-1">

9817The process used to find out if <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45333&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045333&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9818cancer</a>

9819 has spread to other parts of the body is called <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46597&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046597&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9820staging</a>

9821. Most patients with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45395&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045395&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9822osteosarcoma</a>

9823 and UPS are grouped according to whether cancer is <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45754&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045754&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9824localized</a>

9825 or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44058&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044058&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9826metastatic</a>

9827. </p>

9828

9829 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9830

9831 <ul>

9832<li>

9833Localized osteosarcoma or UPS has not spread out of the bone where the cancer started. There may be one or more areas of cancer in the bone that can be removed during <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45570&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045570&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9834surgery</a>

9835.</li>

9836

9837 <li>

9838Metastatic osteosarcoma or UPS has spread from the bone in which the cancer began to other parts of the body. The cancer most often spreads to the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=270740&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000270740&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9839lungs</a>

9840. It may also spread to other bones.</li>

9841

9842 </ul>

9843</div>

9844

9845 <p tabindex="-1">

9846The following tests and procedures may be used to find out if the cancer has spread:</p>

9847

9848 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9849

9850 <ul>

9851<li>

9852<strong>

9853<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45944&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045944&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9854X-ray</a>

9855</strong>

9856: An x-ray of the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=257523&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000257523&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9857organs</a>

9858, such as the chest, and bones inside the body. An x-ray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body. X-rays will be taken of the chest and the area where the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46634&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046634&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9859tumor</a>

9860 formed.</li>

9861

9862 <li>

9863<strong>

9864<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46033&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046033&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9865CT scan</a>

9866 (CAT scan)</strong>

9867: A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest, taken from different angles. The pictures are made by a computer linked to an x-ray machine. A dye may be <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44678&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044678&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9868injected</a>

9869 into a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=476471&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000476471&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9870vein</a>

9871 or swallowed to help the organs or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46683&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046683&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9872tissues</a>

9873 show up more clearly. This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography. Pictures will be taken of the chest and the area where the tumor formed.</li>

9874

9875 <li>

9876<strong>

9877<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46140&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046140&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9878PET scan</a>

9879</strong>

9880: A PET scan is a procedure to find <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45772&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045772&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9881malignant</a>

9882 tumor <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46476&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046476&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9883cells</a>

9884 in the body. A small amount of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=774386&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000774386&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9885radioactive glucose</a>

9886 (sugar) is injected into a vein. The PET <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=386220&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000386220&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9887scanner</a>

9888 rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body. Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do. This procedure is also called positron emission tomography (PET) scan.</li>

9889

9890 <li>

9891<strong>

9892<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=742485&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000742485&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9893PET-CT scan</a>

9894</strong>

9895: A procedure that combines the pictures from a positron emission tomography (PET) scan and a computed tomography (CT) scan. The PET and CT scans are done at the same time on the same machine. The pictures from both scans are combined to make a more detailed picture than either test would make by itself. </li>

9896

9897 <li>

9898<strong>

9899<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45788&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045788&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9900MRI</a>

9901 (magnetic resonance imaging)</strong>

9902: A procedure that uses a magnet, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=651209&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000651209&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9903radio waves</a>

9904, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body. This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).</li>

9905

9906 <li>

9907<strong>

9908<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46499&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046499&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9909Bone scan</a>

9910</strong>

9911: A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone. A very small amount of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46550&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046550&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9912radioactive</a>

9913 material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream. The radioactive material collects in the bones with cancer and is detected by a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=386220&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000386220&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9914scanner</a>

9915.</li>

9916

9917 </ul>

9918</div>

9919

9920 </section>

9921<section>

9922<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

9923There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.</h3>

9924

9925 <p tabindex="-1">

9926Cancer can spread through <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46683&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046683&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9927tissue</a>

9928, the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45764&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045764&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9929lymph system</a>

9930, and the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=270735&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000270735&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9931blood</a>

9932:</p>

9933

9934 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9935

9936 <ul>

9937<li>

9938Tissue. The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas. </li>

9939

9940 <li>

9941Lymph system. The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system. The cancer travels through the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=269462&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000269462&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9942lymph vessels</a>

9943 to other parts of the body. </li>

9944

9945 <li>

9946Blood. The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood. The cancer travels through the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45020&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045020&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9947blood vessels</a>

9948 to other parts of the body. </li>

9949

9950 </ul>

9951</div>

9952

9953 </section>

9954<section>

9955<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

9956Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.</h3>

9957

9958 <p tabindex="-1">

9959When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46710&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046710&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9960metastasis</a>

9961. Cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46476&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046476&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9962cells</a>

9963 break away from where they began (the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45847&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045847&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9964primary tumor</a>

9965) and travel through the lymph system or blood.</p>

9966

9967 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9968

9969 <ul>

9970<li>

9971Lymph system. The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46634&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046634&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9972tumor</a>

9973 (<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44058&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044058&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9974metastatic</a>

9975 tumor) in another part of the body.</li>

9976

9977 <li>

9978Blood. The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.</li>

9979

9980 </ul>

9981</div>

9982

9983 <p tabindex="-1">

9984The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor. For example, if osteosarcoma spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually osteosarcoma cells. The disease is metastatic osteosarcoma, not lung cancer.</p>

9985

9986 <div data-embed-button="media_entity_embed" data-entity-embed-display="view_mode:media.video_display_medium_no_title" data-entity-type="media" data-caption="" class="embedded-entity align-center">

9987

9988 <figure class="video">

9989<div class="flex-video widescreen" data-video-url="https://www.youtube.com/embed/fQwar_-QdiQ?feature=oembed&amp;autoplay=1" data-video-title="metastasis: how cancer spreads">

9990

9991 <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/fQwar_-QdiQ?rel=0" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" title="metastasis: how cancer spreads" alt="metastasis: how cancer spreads" allowfullscreen="">

9992</iframe>

9993

9994 </div>

9995

9996 <figcaption class="caption-container">

9997

9998 Many cancer deaths are caused when cancer moves from the original tumor and spreads to other tissues and organs. This is called metastatic cancer. This animation shows how cancer cells travel from the place in the body where they first formed to other parts of the body.

9999 </figcaption>

10000</figure>

10001</div>

10002

10003 </section>

10004<section>

10005<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

10006Sometimes osteosarcoma and UPS of bone come back after treatment.</h3>

10007

10008 <p tabindex="-1">

10009The cancer may <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46556&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046556&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10010recur</a>

10011 (come back) in the bone or in other parts of the body. Osteosarcoma and UPS most often recur in the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=270740&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000270740&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10012lung</a>

10013, bone, or both. When osteosarcoma recurs, it is usually within 18 months after treatment is completed. </p>

10014

10015 </section>

10016</div>

10017

10018 </div>

10019

10020 <h3>

10021Treatment Option Overview</h3>

10022

10023 <div class="pdq-sections">

10024

10025 <div class="pdq-sections">

10026

10027 <div class="key-points">

10028

10029 <h3 do-not-show="toc">

10030Key Points</h3>

10031

10032 <div>

10033

10034 <ul>

10035<li>

10036There are different types of treatment for patients with osteosarcoma or undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS).</li>

10037

10038 <li>

10039Children with osteosarcoma or UPS should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children. </li>

10040

10041 <li>

10042Five types of standard treatment are used:

10043 <ul>

10044<li>

10045Surgery</li>

10046

10047 <li>

10048Chemotherapy</li>

10049

10050 <li>

10051Radiation therapy</li>

10052

10053 <li>

10054Samarium</li>

10055

10056 <li>

10057Targeted therapy </li>

10058

10059 </ul>

10060</li>

10061

10062 <li>

10063Treatment for osteosarcoma or UPS may cause side effects.</li>

10064

10065 <li>

10066New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials. </li>

10067

10068 <li>

10069Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.</li>

10070

10071 <li>

10072Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.</li>

10073

10074 <li>

10075Follow-up tests may be needed.</li>

10076

10077 </ul>

10078</div>

10079

10080 </div>

10081

10082 <section>

10083<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

10084There are different types of treatment for patients with osteosarcoma or undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS).</h3>

10085

10086 <p tabindex="-1">

10087Different types of treatment are available for children with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45395&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045395&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10088osteosarcoma</a>

10089 or UPS of bone. Some treatments are <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44930&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044930&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10090standard</a>

10091 (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45961&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045961&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10092clinical trials</a>

10093. A treatment clinical trial is a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=651211&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000651211&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10094research study</a>

10095 meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45333&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045333&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10096cancer</a>

10097. When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.</p>

10098

10099 <p tabindex="-1">

10100Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered. Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.</p>

10101

10102 </section>

10103<section>

10104<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

10105Children with osteosarcoma or UPS should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children. </h3>

10106

10107 <p tabindex="-1">

10108Treatment will be overseen by a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=693555&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000693555&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10109pediatric oncologist</a>

10110, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer. The pediatric oncologist works with other <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46245&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046245&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10111pediatric</a>

10112 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=650566&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000650566&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10113health care providers</a>

10114 who are experts in treating osteosarcoma and UPS and who specialize in certain areas of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=482419&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000482419&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10115medicine</a>

10116. These may include the following <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=478785&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000478785&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10117specialists</a>

10118:</p>

10119

10120 <div class="pdq-content-list">

10121

10122 <ul>

10123<li>

10124<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=757278&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000757278&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10125Pediatrician</a>

10126.</li>

10127

10128 <li>

10129Orthopedic <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44306&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044306&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10130surgeon</a>

10131 who has experience treating bone <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46634&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046634&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10132tumors</a>

10133.</li>

10134

10135 <li>

10136<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46546&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046546&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10137Radiation oncologist</a>

10138.</li>

10139

10140 <li>

10141<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=318825&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000318825&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10142Rehabilitation specialist</a>

10143.</li>

10144

10145 <li>

10146<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=318821&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000318821&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10147Pediatric nurse specialist</a>

10148.</li>

10149

10150 <li>

10151<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44730&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044730&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10152Social worker</a>

10153.</li>

10154

10155 <li>

10156<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=690737&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000690737&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10157Child-life specialist</a>

10158.</li>

10159

10160 <li>

10161<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44716&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044716&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10162Psychologist</a>

10163.</li>

10164

10165 <li>

10166<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=809738&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000809738&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10167Fertility specialist</a>

10168.</li>

10169

10170 </ul>

10171</div>

10172

10173 <p tabindex="-1">

10174For information about types and monitoring of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=390292&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000390292&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10175late effects</a>

10176 in childhood and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776825&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776825&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10177adolescent</a>

10178 cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=450125&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000450125&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10179survivors</a>

10180, see <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-pdq">

10181Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer</a>

10182.</p>

10183

10184 </section>

10185<section>

10186<h3 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

10187Five types of standard treatment are used:</h3>

10188

10189 <section>

10190<h4 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

10191Surgery</h4>

10192

10193 <p tabindex="-1">

10194 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45570&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045570&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10195Surgery</a>

10196 to remove the entire tumor will be done when possible. <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45214&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045214&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10197Chemotherapy</a>

10198 may be given before surgery to make the tumor smaller. This is called <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45800&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045800&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10199neoadjuvant</a>

10200 chemotherapy. Chemotherapy is given so less bone <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46683&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046683&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10201tissue</a>

10202 needs to be removed and there are fewer problems after surgery. </p>

10203

10204 <p tabindex="-1">

10205The following types of surgery may be done:</p>

10206

10207 <div class="pdq-content-list">

10208

10209 <ul>

10210<li>

10211<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=446983&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000446983&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10212Wide local excision</a>

10213: Surgery to remove the cancer and some healthy tissue around it.</li>

10214

10215 <li>

10216<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=689062&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000689062&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10217Limb-sparing surgery</a>

10218: Removal of the tumor in a limb (arm or leg) without <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46210&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046210&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10219amputation</a>

10220, so the use and appearance of the limb is saved. Most patients with osteosarcoma in a limb can be treated with limb-sparing surgery. The tumor is removed by wide local <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=269459&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000269459&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10221excision</a>

10222. Tissue and bone that are removed may be replaced with a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46373&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046373&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10223graft</a>

10224 using tissue and bone taken from another part of the patient's body, or with an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=285636&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000285636&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10225implant</a>

10226 such as artificial bone. If a fracture is found at the time of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46450&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046450&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10227diagnosis</a>

10228 or during chemotherapy before surgery, limb-sparing surgery may still be possible in some cases. If the surgeon is not able to remove all of the tumor and enough healthy tissue around it, an amputation may be done.</li>

10229

10230 <li>

10231 Amputation: Surgery to remove part or all of an arm or leg. This may be done when it is not possible to remove all of the tumor in limb-sparing surgery. The patient may be fitted with a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46542&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046542&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10232prosthesis</a>

10233 (artificial limb) after amputation.</li>

10234

10235 <li>

10236<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=693564&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000693564&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10237Rotationplasty</a>

10238: Surgery to remove the tumor and the knee <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=458080&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000458080&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10239joint</a>

10240. The part of the leg that remains below the knee is then attached to the part of the leg that remains above the knee, with the foot facing backward and the ankle acting as a knee. A prosthesis may then be attached to the foot.</li>

10241

10242 </ul>

10243</div>

10244

10245 <p tabindex="-1">

10246Studies have shown that <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44301&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044301&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10247survival</a>

10248 is the same whether the first surgery done is a limb-sparing surgery or an amputation.</p>

10249

10250 <p tabindex="-1">

10251After the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, patients are given chemotherapy to kill any cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46476&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046476&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10252cells</a>

10253 that are left in the area where the tumor was removed or that have spread to other parts of the body. Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45587&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045587&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10254adjuvant therapy</a>

10255.</p>

10256

10257 </section>

10258<section>

10259<h4 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

10260Chemotherapy</h4>

10261

10262 <p tabindex="-1">

10263Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=348921&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000348921&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10264drugs</a>

10265 to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing. When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44678&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044678&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10266injected</a>

10267 into a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=476471&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000476471&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10268vein</a>

10269 or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=301626&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000301626&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10270systemic chemotherapy</a>

10271).</p>

10272

10273 <p tabindex="-1">

10274<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45650&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045650&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10275Combination chemotherapy</a>

10276 is the use of more than one anticancer drug.</p>

10277

10278 <p tabindex="-1">

10279Chemotherapy is usually given before and after surgery to remove the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45847&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045847&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10280primary tumor</a>

10281.</p>

10282

10283 <p tabindex="-1">

10284For more information, see <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/drugs/bone" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/drugs/bone">

10285Drugs Approved for Bone Cancer</a>

10286.</p>

10287

10288 </section>

10289<section>

10290<h4 type="keypoint" do-not-show="toc">

10291Radiation therapy</h4>

10292

10293 <p tabindex="-1">

10294<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44971&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044971&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10295Radiation therapy</a>

10296 is a cancer treatment that uses high-energy <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45944&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045944&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10297x-rays</a>

10298 or other types of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="https://www.cancer.gov/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45072&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045072&amp;version=patient&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

10299radiation</a>

10300 to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing. There are two types of radiation therapy: </p>

10301

10302 <div class="pdq-content-list">

10303

10304 <ul>

10305<li>
